subject: RE: [junit] Separate Package for Test Cases or not ?
msgSnippet: That s fine for an open source project where the tests are an integral piece of the development process, and users may modify the application to suite their
messageBody:
That's fine for an open source project where the tests are an integral piece of the development process, and users may modify the application to suite their needs. But I don't think it's a very good idea in a business environment. We require a unit test log to close any bug, so this keeps the developers from forgetting to run them.
 
At my company we put the tests in the same java package but in a different cvs module. Our build can work with or without the tests and the two cvs modules share a very similar directory structure. This allows us to easily maintain the code we distribute without cluttering it up with unit tests and still be able to test at the package level with all the benefits it affords (or drawbacks depending on your philosophy)...
 
Chris

Subject: [junit] Separate Package for Test Cases or not ?

According this topic I found two different views:
-) In the sourceforge FAQ they propose to use a separate test package
for the unit tests.
-) In various documents linked on the JUnit homepage (e.g. JUnit bets
practices) they propose to keep the unit tests in the package of the
classes to be tested.

Personally I like the separate package more, as I don't want to ship
the unit tests with the project. At no costs I want to manually
exclude the test classes during shipment. Addiditonally I simply find
this approach more structured - in our last project we had for each
package a .test package.
The separate package however has the main drawback for me that I cant
test package private methods. This forces me to make more methods
public than I want just for testing purposes.

What are your experiences and preferences in this area ?

Chris Lewold
